globalMetadata.title: Good Thinking - NHS approved wellbeing service
globalMetadata.description: Anxious, stressed, depressed or having trouble sleeping? Find NHS-approved mental health tools and advice to support you.

links.text: Find the right help for you

footer.description: Good Thinking provides a range of resources to help Londoners improve their mental wellbeing.

subscribeFooterText.copy: Get the latest tips and resources for Londoners delivered to your inbox every month.

partners.name: Transformation Partners in Health and Care

howToUseSection.bodyText:
Find support, advice and resources by:

  • Mental health concern

Sleep, Anxiety, Low mood, Stress.

  • Audience

Young people, Employers and employees, Someone who is grieving, Faith and belief communities.

  • Type of support

Self-assessments, free apps, podcasts, videos, how to guides, workbooks.

Get expert advice from Good Thinking

The Good Thinking team has created a broad range of advice in collaboration with clinical and subject-area experts, designed to support Londoners with everyday mental health challenges.

In our Latest Advice section, you'll find short guides with tips and resource recommendations to help you with a range of concerns including dealing with uncertainty, money worries, getting enough sleep and coping with bereavement. 

If you’re looking for advice on a specific subject, type in your topic in the ‘search﻿’ box at the top of the page.

howToUseSection.bodyText:
Use the Good Thinking self-assessment tool

Our in-depth, clinically validated self-assessments are a thorough assessment of both your mental and physical wellbeing. They may seem quite ‘medical’ because they are based on the types of questions a doctor or a psychologist might ask you.

  • Each self-assessment takes around 20 minutes to complete
  • Answer questions about yourself or someone you may be concerned about
  • You’ll get a personalised list of recommended actions to take forward

Find the right help for you

Tell us what you're looking for help with and who you're looking for help for and you’ll then receive personalised recommendations for apps and other resources to meet your needs.

adviceData.title: Loneliness Awareness Week 2025:  Tackling social isolation across London
adviceData.subtitle: It’s not always easy to connect with others in a big city – but there is lots of help available from Good Thinking and other organisations.

metadata.description: To mark Loneliness Awareness Week 2025, Good Thinking looks at eight London initiatives that are helping to tackle social isolation and boost mental health.
metadata.title: Loneliness Awareness Week 2025

small.name: small_WCL mind peer support - SAM Apr 2025 (600 x 400 px).png

thumbnail.name: thumbnail_WCL mind peer support - SAM Apr 2025 (600 x 400 px).png

attributes.name: WCL mind peer support - SAM Apr 2025 (600 x 400 px).png

contentSections.content:
What do you think of when you hear the word ‘lonely’? Is it something you’ve experienced yourself? How did you cope with it and move forward?

Sometimes we all feel lonely. In a huge city like London, it can often feel counter intuitive to experience a sense of isolation. Despite being surrounded by millions of people every day, building and maintaining those important connections with family, friends or colleagues can be surprisingly difficult.

There’s no shame in admitting to feeling lonely, and this Loneliness Awareness Week (9-15 June) is all about reducing the stigma associated with this natural human emotion.

It’s estimated that 1 in 12 Londoners experience loneliness, which can have a significant impact on mental health and wellbeing, exacerbating stress, anxiety and low mood. Perhaps you’ve moved to London recently and don’t know many people yet. Maybe you’ve lost a partner or close friend and are really missing them. Or you might be facing discrimination and feeling excluded from society.

When we asked our Digital Health Ambassadors (aged 16-25) what their advice would be for any young person who is feeling lonely, the most common tip was to talk to someone you trust. As one of them said, “Talk to a friend about it… maybe someone you can trust with opening up to and just venting on how you’re feeling. That might really help with feelings of loneliness.”

With loneliness sometimes leading to low mood, anxiety, stress, sleep problems and other mental health concerns, it’s important that you take action and get the right support.

In this article, we look at some initiatives that are helping Londoners to tackle loneliness and isolation at all ages and stages of life.

Our guide to the five ways to good mental wellbeing might also be useful if you’re feeling lonely. It contains tips on how to connect with other people, be physically active, learn new skills, give to others and pay attention to the present moment.

For updates about what’s going on during Loneliness Awareness Week, visit the website and follow @marmalade_trust on social media.

tabs.title: Good Thinking Small Grants Programme: London Borough of Newham
tabs.content:
In 2024, Good Thinking supported 10 community organisations across the London Borough of Newham to develop initiatives designed to improve mental health and wellbeing across the patch through the provision of small pots of funding. Through the programme, organisations were trained as Good Thinking ‘super users’ to be confident in championing and sharing the wide range of mental health and wellbeing resources available through the Good Thinking platform with members of the community.

Aishah Help

Aishah Help is a non-profit, women-led organisation in the London Borough of Newham that supports disadvantaged communities to achieve their personal, social and economic potential. Through participation in Good Thinking’s Small Grants Programme, Aishah Help organised two befriending events that addressed social isolation among older adults by creating opportunities for meaningful social interactions, particularly through inter-generational activities to help promote inclusivity and support participants to rebuild their confidence, resilience and sense of purpose.

Read more


Alternatives Trust East London

Alternatives Trust East is a small charity that empowers vulnerable families in the London Borough of Newham to transform their lives. The charity provides a range of services, including advocacy to address the causes of poverty, practical help, one-to-one parenting support, counselling and therapeutic support. 

Through training as Good Thinking ‘super users’, Alternatives staff enabling built confidence to share mental health and wellbeing resources with service users across a range of forums, including weekly Family Hub social events and individual counselling sessions.

Read more


Inspire Women, Men and Children

Inspire UK works with BAME communities in East London (Newham and Tower Hamlets) as well as migrants and refugees arriving in the UK by providing targeted, culturally sensitive and holistic support services to meet their needs. Through the Small Grants Programme, Inspire adopted a multi-channel approach to community engagement, using culturally tailored approaches and collaborating with trusted community leaders and organisations to reach the diverse communities of Newham.

One participant said that Inspire “really made me feel like I wasn’t alone in this journey”.

Read more

tabs.title: Good Gym
tabs.content:
GoodGym is a unique community of runners, walkers and cyclists who combine getting fit with doing good. From planting trees at local parks to cleaning up community centres and helping older people in the community with things like maintenance and gardening, GoodGym has over 25,000 members across London and beyond. It’s an opportunity to connect with others, reduce isolation and loneliness in the community and make a difference.

Read more

tabs.title: South East London Mind's ‘Mindful Mums’ network
tabs.content:
These award-winning, free wellbeing groups in Bromley, Lewisham, Greenwich, Lambeth and Southwark help pregnant women and new mothers to look after their mental and emotional health during pregnancy and their baby’s first year. It’s about taking time out to make meaningful connections, de-stress and meet others going through a similar experience to talk and reduce feelings of isolation.

Read more

tabs.title: The Great Friendship Project
tabs.content:
The Great Friendship Project supports young adults through campaigns, research, support and fun activities, including social walks, board game events and nights out. With a community of 43,000 people across the UK, 73% of attendees say that the project has helped to reduce social isolation.

Read our interview with David Gradon, founder of The Great Friendship Project

tabs.title: West Central London Mind’s Community Living Well Peer Support Network
tabs.content:
This network helps residents of Kensington and Chelsea to reduce isolation, make new connections and access support based on their own personal and shared experiences of mental health concerns.

Daisy Petrow of WCL Mind, describes it as “a welcoming space where residents can connect with others, share experiences and find mutual support”.

Read more
